issues.title: Conan package for http-parser
issues.body:
Hello,
Do you know about [Conan](https://github.com/conan-io/conan)?
[Conan](http://docs.conan.io/en/latest/) is modern dependency manager for C++. And will be great if your library will be available via package manager for other developers.

[Here](https://github.com/bincrafters/conan-templates) you can find example, how you can create package for the library. 

If you have any questions, just ask :-)

issues.title: Test "CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST" maybe worng
issues.body:
See: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235#issuecomment-356903686

The `CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST` test case input has `Content-Length: 10` and a body `"blarfcicle"`, but the test expects [`.body= ""`](https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/blob/master/test.c#L1102) !

[The RFC says](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3):
> _The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
    Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field.  Request message
   framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
   not define any use for a message body._

i.e. A request that says `Content-Length: 10` has a 10-byte body irrespective of the method being `CONNECT`.

The `CONNECT` scemantics are defined here: [RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6). It talks about the client ignoring *responses( with Content-Length in, however, that is not relevant to this test *request* test case.

>    _A server MUST NOT send any Transfer-Encoding or Content-Length header
   fields in a 2xx (Successful) response to CONNECT.  A client MUST
   ignore any Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header fields received
   in a successful response to CONNECT._

[RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6) goes on to say that a payload on a `CONNECT` request has no defined meaning, but it does not disallow it:

>  _A payload within a CONNECT request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a CONNECT request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request._

So, this line may be wrong: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235/files#diff-5c62f371bf37583234d2462ad49ce33dR1837

issues.title: HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields
issues.body:
According to https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/AsImplemented.html, HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields, and single CR + LF pair (or just LF) after a request line signals the end of request. But current http-parser waits for 2nd CR + LF pair. See how apache works: ``` $ telnet 127.0.0.1 80 Trying 127.0.0.1... Connected to 127.0.0.1. Escape character is '^]'. GET /

It works!

This is the default web page for this server.

The web server software is running but no content has been added, yet.

Connection closed by foreign host. ```

issues.title: When parsing response that omits status message text, on_status is never called
issues.body:
On status callback does not get invoked when we're dealing with a web server that omits the status text from the status line. Examples of servers doing this are kijiji.

Example from in the wild:
```
GET 
https://www.kijiji.ca/h-lloydminster-ab/1700095

Status: HTTP/1.1 200
```

Server is advertised as being nginx.

When parsing the response, `on_status` will never be called. Not sure if this is intended or not, I started looking into the spec for this and didn't see any `MUST`'s with regards to the status text. I came up with a solution to work around this personally so I don't care anymore, just FYI.

issues.title: add .deps and .dirstamp to .gitignore
issues.body:
I use http-parser in another project as a submodule. When I run autotools configure, it creates in the http-parser sub directory a directory and a file:

```
[user@localhost http-parser]$ git status
HEAD detached from 8d9e5db
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	.deps/
	.dirstamp

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
[user@localhost http-parser]$
```

It would be super-nice to have `git status` **not** warn me about these two files generated by autotools.

added ignore_header_transfer_encodig_chunked and ignore_header_content_length to settings.

ignore_header_content_length:

issues.title: How to disable automatic chunks decoding?
issues.body:
> The parser decodes the transfer-encoding for both requests and responses transparently. That is, a chunked encoding is decoded before being sent to the on_body callback.

Is it possible to configure parser not to decode chunked encoding?
I would like to receive chunks in `on_body` unmodified.

issues.title: http header parsing
issues.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

issues.title: makefile: Flexible install fixes
issues.body:
Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

issues.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
issues.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

issues.title: http-parser fails to detect chunked encoding at the end of a list
issues.body:
Given the header:

```
Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked\r\n
```

The parser will not set chunked encoding when it should:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.1

Encodings are applied left to right and removed from right to left. If the parser encounters the `chunked` token as the last item when the Transfer-Encoding value is a comma separated list, it should consider the message body to be chunk encoded.

I haven't actually tried this so I might be wrong but I see no code for finding a comma in Transfer-Encoding. However, the parser DOES handle comma separated lists correctly for the Connection header.

doc: standardize project name

PR-URL: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/398
Reviewed-By: Ben Noordhuis <info@bnoordhuis.nl>
Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

makefile: fix dangling symlink in uninstall

Fix symbolic links so they are now relative, and also removes a
dangling symlink that was left there with make uninstall
(libhttp_parser.so was left pointing to a non-existant file previously).
Don't hard-code the library name, match the file names of `make install`.

PR-URL: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/391
Reviewed-By: James M Snell <jasnell@gmail.com>
Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

makefile: fixed DESTDIR

Modified the Makefile so that it actually works. As it is now, symlinks
will point to the fully qualified path of wherever your DESTDIR was: so
one would end up with symlinks like:

    /usr/local/lib/libhttp_parser.so.2.7

pointing to:

    /tmp/http-parser-git/pkg/http-parser-git/usr/local/lib/libhttp_parser.so.2.7.1.

This caused quite a bit of trouble when trying to package it, this
patch makes it work.

PR-URL: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/391
Reviewed-By: James M Snell <jasnell@gmail.com>
Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

Makefile: set install_name on macos

install_name on Mach-O is similar to SONAME on ELF, except that it needs
a full path instead of just the basename.

Fixes: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/issues/356
PR-URL: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/358
Reviewed-By: Ben Noordhuis <info@bnoordhuis.nl>

Update license boilerplate.

The boilerplate included attribution to NGINX that created confusion
because NGINX is distributed under a different license (BSD, not MIT.)

To the best of everyone's knowledge, no actual NGINX code remains.
Remove the attribution to clear up the confusion.

Fixes: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/issues/389
PR-URL: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/390
Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

simplify parsing M-SEARCH method, group P methods

can use same switch-lookup for '-' char case
move PROPFIND and PURGE to be next to the other P methods

change IS_ALPHA(ch) to  A <= ch <= Z
(very slight optimization, only uppercase will match in switch)

While at it, create a symlink the from SONAME to the library, instead of

Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

parser: HTTP_STATUS_MAP(XX) and enum http_status

This patch provides an enum for the standardized HTTP status codes.
Additionally, the HTTP_STATUS_MAP(XX) can be used for other purposes as
well, such as code-to-name lookups and code-based switch statements.

Reviewed-By: Fedor Indutny <fedor@indutny.com>

parser: returning 2 from on_headers_complete

Returning `2` from on_headers_complete will tell parser that it
should not expect neither a body nor any futher responses on
this connection. This is useful for handling responses to a
CONNECT request which may not contain `Upgrade` or
`Connection: upgrade` headers.

See: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/6198

pull_requests.title: Allow non-standard HTTP method
pull_requests.body:
This change adds non-standard HTTP method support.  We added new
callback on_method of type http_data_cb, which notifies incoming
method.  For non-standard HTTP method, method field in struct
http_parser becomes HTTP_METHOD_UNKNOWN.

The non-standard HTTP method is disabled by default, and must be
explicitly enabled by giving -DHTTP_PARSER_METHOD_CB=1 on build time.
This is for backward compatibility; because non-standard HTTP method
is now accepted rather than rejected.

pull_requests.title: Fix: suppress warning C4244 on MSVC
pull_requests.body:
MSVC 2015 gives some warnings on http_parser.c with 

> warning C4244: '=' : conversion from 'int' to 'uint16_t', possible loss of data
> It will supress this warning.

pull_requests.title: http_parser: skip lws/rws in header field
pull_requests.body:
Skip whitespace from the left and the right sides of the header field.

See: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5844

cc @jasnell

pull_requests.title: Added support for compiling on MinGW platform
pull_requests.body:
Added rules to compile on MinGW platforms (Microsoft Windows environments):
- Use 'gcc' as compiler.
- Generate DLL file when compiling the library.
- Disable -fPIC when compiling the library (on MinGW platforms all code is already position independent and setting this flag issues an error).

pull_requests.title: Introduce raw data callbacks
pull_requests.body:
These callbacks can be used when developing transparent HTTP traffic analysis and filtering. 
The main goal of it is to handle transmitted data as-is, but having ability to distinguish data between headers, bodies and different requests.

pull_requests.title: Add support for digits, '+', '-', and '.' to the scheme of a URI
pull_requests.body: Addresses #275.

pull_requests.title: Make library symlinks relative
pull_requests.body: This allows distributions to be more easily relocatable, such as when bottling this library in Homebrew.

pull_requests.title: Implement on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks
pull_requests.body:
This patch adds on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks. 
When parser finish processing of new portion of data (or when it switches between header/body state) it run these callbacks, attaching exact stream data.
These callbacks called after usual header and body callbacks.

Patch contains bug: after parsing error detected it still can call raw callback, so we need to check error status of a parser inside raw callbacks.

Patch based at old revision, so we need to dig into parser logic again.
Base revision: 959f4cb12748ea3aa2c4ec3183ff4acbf0fd222f

pull_requests.title: Allow repeatable calls to 'make install'.
pull_requests.body:
Currently if `make install` is invoked multiple times it fails due to it trying to recreate the `libhttp_parser.so` symlink. 

Adding the `-f` flag to the `ln` invocations fixes this, but will change the default http-parser used to the newly installed version if there are multiple versions installed. I _think_ this is what we want to do anyway since we are clobbering any existing `http-parser.h` during install, so not repointing the symlink would result in a mismatch between the default library and header versions.

The alternative would be to version `http-parser.h` and add a symlink for it, while trying to ensure we always update both symlinks atomically.

pull_requests.title: Added support for SOURCE
pull_requests.body:
As per tweets: https://twitter.com/indutny/status/557499042243289088

It seems new handling for upgrade was added at some point, which makes the tests break. Unfortunately I don't have time to work out how to make the tests pass again.

SOURCE should essentially be handled like Upgrade, I believe, and switched to data/tcp mode after parsing headers.

/cc @indutny @bnoordhuis

pull_requests.title: Solaris doesn't necessarily have stdint.h, use inttypes.h
pull_requests.body:
Solaris doesn't necessarily have `stdint.h`, it's more portable to use `sys/inttypes.h`.

See:
http://wiki.opencsw.org/porting-faq#toc1

pull_requests.title: Add two hooks to be executed when a chunk is downloaded.
pull_requests.body:
One hook is executed right before receiving a new chunk. The second
one is executed just after. parsertrace.c is updated to use those
hooks for display.

I am using this for experimentation with rendering. This is more reliable than looking at timestamps to know where chunks start and end.

Just FYI, HTTPbis is discouraging the use of multi-line headers; from http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-11#section-3.2 : 

   Historically, HTTP header field values could be extended over
   multiple lines by preceding each extra line with at least one space
   or horizontal tab character (line folding).  This specification
   deprecates such line folding except within the message/http media
   type (Section 10.3.1).  HTTP/1.1 senders MUST NOT produce messages
   that include line folding (i.e., that contain any field-content that
   matches the obs-fold rule) unless the message is intended for
   packaging within the message/http media type.  HTTP/1.1 recipients
   SHOULD accept line folding and replace any embedded obs-fold
   whitespace with a single SP prior to interpreting the field value or
   forwarding the message downstream.

I.e., the parser still SHOULD be able to handle them, but the spec now admits they're not widely supported.

@pgriess - With HTTP/1.0 or earlier, Keep-Alive is disabled by default. Therefore, I think that we do not need it. Keep-Alive is used if and only if the response has `Connection: Keep-Alive` (or legacy `Keep-Alive:`, but http-parser does not seem to support it).

[EDIT] I may understand what you mean. HTTP/1.0 server sends `Connection: Keep-Alive`, but the body length may be unable to be determined.

Yeah, if the client and server both agree on keep-alive (i.e. by both sending "Connection: keep-alive" headers), we're dealing with the same situation as HTTP/1.1: we have a bytestream that contains a response with no body followed by another response. The case we're dealing with here is not that we can't determine the response length -- it's that we know that the length is 0.

issues.title: Conan package for http-parser
issues.body:
Hello,
Do you know about [Conan](https://github.com/conan-io/conan)?
[Conan](http://docs.conan.io/en/latest/) is modern dependency manager for C++. And will be great if your library will be available via package manager for other developers.

[Here](https://github.com/bincrafters/conan-templates) you can find example, how you can create package for the library. 

If you have any questions, just ask :-)

issues.title: Test "CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST" maybe worng
issues.body:
See: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235#issuecomment-356903686

The `CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST` test case input has `Content-Length: 10` and a body `"blarfcicle"`, but the test expects [`.body= ""`](https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/blob/master/test.c#L1102) !

[The RFC says](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3):
> _The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
    Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field.  Request message
   framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
   not define any use for a message body._

i.e. A request that says `Content-Length: 10` has a 10-byte body irrespective of the method being `CONNECT`.

The `CONNECT` scemantics are defined here: [RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6). It talks about the client ignoring *responses( with Content-Length in, however, that is not relevant to this test *request* test case.

>    _A server MUST NOT send any Transfer-Encoding or Content-Length header
   fields in a 2xx (Successful) response to CONNECT.  A client MUST
   ignore any Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header fields received
   in a successful response to CONNECT._

[RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6) goes on to say that a payload on a `CONNECT` request has no defined meaning, but it does not disallow it:

>  _A payload within a CONNECT request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a CONNECT request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request._

So, this line may be wrong: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235/files#diff-5c62f371bf37583234d2462ad49ce33dR1837

issues.title: HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields
issues.body:
According to https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/AsImplemented.html, HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields, and single CR + LF pair (or just LF) after a request line signals the end of request. But current http-parser waits for 2nd CR + LF pair. See how apache works: ``` $ telnet 127.0.0.1 80 Trying 127.0.0.1... Connected to 127.0.0.1. Escape character is '^]'. GET /

It works!

This is the default web page for this server.

The web server software is running but no content has been added, yet.

Connection closed by foreign host. ```

issues.title: When parsing response that omits status message text, on_status is never called
issues.body:
On status callback does not get invoked when we're dealing with a web server that omits the status text from the status line. Examples of servers doing this are kijiji.

Example from in the wild:
```
GET 
https://www.kijiji.ca/h-lloydminster-ab/1700095

Status: HTTP/1.1 200
```

Server is advertised as being nginx.

When parsing the response, `on_status` will never be called. Not sure if this is intended or not, I started looking into the spec for this and didn't see any `MUST`'s with regards to the status text. I came up with a solution to work around this personally so I don't care anymore, just FYI.

issues.title: How to disable automatic chunks decoding?
issues.body:
> The parser decodes the transfer-encoding for both requests and responses transparently. That is, a chunked encoding is decoded before being sent to the on_body callback.

Is it possible to configure parser not to decode chunked encoding?
I would like to receive chunks in `on_body` unmodified.

issues.title: http header parsing
issues.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

issues.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
issues.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

issues.title: http-parser fails to detect chunked encoding at the end of a list
issues.body:
Given the header:

```
Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked\r\n
```

The parser will not set chunked encoding when it should:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.1

Encodings are applied left to right and removed from right to left. If the parser encounters the `chunked` token as the last item when the Transfer-Encoding value is a comma separated list, it should consider the message body to be chunk encoded.

I haven't actually tried this so I might be wrong but I see no code for finding a comma in Transfer-Encoding. However, the parser DOES handle comma separated lists correctly for the Connection header.

(libhttp_parser.so was left pointing to a non-existant file previously).
Don't hard-code the library name, match the file names of `make install`.

makefile: fixed DESTDIR

Modified the Makefile so that it actually works. As it is now, symlinks
will point to the fully qualified path of wherever your DESTDIR was: so
one would end up with symlinks like:

    /usr/local/lib/libhttp_parser.so.2.7

pointing to:

    /tmp/http-parser-git/pkg/http-parser-git/usr/local/lib/libhttp_parser.so.2.7.1.

This caused quite a bit of trouble when trying to package it, this
patch makes it work.

a full path instead of just the basename.

pull_requests.title: http header parsing
pull_requests.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

pull_requests.title: parser: fix handling of newlines before HTTP responses
pull_requests.body: This diff fixes ignoring of CR and LF chars received before HTTP response's start line the same way as they are handled with HTTP_REQUEST and HTTP_BOTH parser types.

pull_requests.title: makefile: Flexible install fixes
pull_requests.body:
Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

pull_requests.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
pull_requests.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

pull_requests.title: Allow non-standard HTTP method
pull_requests.body:
This change adds non-standard HTTP method support.  We added new
callback on_method of type http_data_cb, which notifies incoming
method.  For non-standard HTTP method, method field in struct
http_parser becomes HTTP_METHOD_UNKNOWN.

The non-standard HTTP method is disabled by default, and must be
explicitly enabled by giving -DHTTP_PARSER_METHOD_CB=1 on build time.
This is for backward compatibility; because non-standard HTTP method
is now accepted rather than rejected.

pull_requests.title: Fix: suppress warning C4244 on MSVC
pull_requests.body:
MSVC 2015 gives some warnings on http_parser.c with 

> warning C4244: '=' : conversion from 'int' to 'uint16_t', possible loss of data
> It will supress this warning.

pull_requests.title: http_parser: skip lws/rws in header field
pull_requests.body:
Skip whitespace from the left and the right sides of the header field.

See: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5844

cc @jasnell

pull_requests.title: Added support for compiling on MinGW platform
pull_requests.body:
Added rules to compile on MinGW platforms (Microsoft Windows environments):
- Use 'gcc' as compiler.
- Generate DLL file when compiling the library.
- Disable -fPIC when compiling the library (on MinGW platforms all code is already position independent and setting this flag issues an error).

pull_requests.title: Introduce raw data callbacks
pull_requests.body:
These callbacks can be used when developing transparent HTTP traffic analysis and filtering. 
The main goal of it is to handle transmitted data as-is, but having ability to distinguish data between headers, bodies and different requests.

pull_requests.title: Add support for digits, '+', '-', and '.' to the scheme of a URI
pull_requests.body: Addresses #275.

pull_requests.title: Make library symlinks relative
pull_requests.body: This allows distributions to be more easily relocatable, such as when bottling this library in Homebrew.

pull_requests.title: Implement on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks
pull_requests.body:
This patch adds on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks. 
When parser finish processing of new portion of data (or when it switches between header/body state) it run these callbacks, attaching exact stream data.
These callbacks called after usual header and body callbacks.

Patch contains bug: after parsing error detected it still can call raw callback, so we need to check error status of a parser inside raw callbacks.

Patch based at old revision, so we need to dig into parser logic again.
Base revision: 959f4cb12748ea3aa2c4ec3183ff4acbf0fd222f

pull_requests.title: Allow repeatable calls to 'make install'.
pull_requests.body:
Currently if `make install` is invoked multiple times it fails due to it trying to recreate the `libhttp_parser.so` symlink. 

Adding the `-f` flag to the `ln` invocations fixes this, but will change the default http-parser used to the newly installed version if there are multiple versions installed. I _think_ this is what we want to do anyway since we are clobbering any existing `http-parser.h` during install, so not repointing the symlink would result in a mismatch between the default library and header versions.

The alternative would be to version `http-parser.h` and add a symlink for it, while trying to ensure we always update both symlinks atomically.

pull_requests.title: Added support for SOURCE

pull_requests.title: Add two hooks to be executed when a chunk is downloaded.
pull_requests.body:
One hook is executed right before receiving a new chunk. The second
one is executed just after. parsertrace.c is updated to use those
hooks for display.

I am using this for experimentation with rendering. This is more reliable than looking at timestamps to know where chunks start and end.

ok

Just FYI, HTTPbis is discouraging the use of multi-line headers; from http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-11#section-3.2 : 

   Historically, HTTP header field values could be extended over
   multiple lines by preceding each extra line with at least one space
   or horizontal tab character (line folding).  This specification
   deprecates such line folding except within the message/http media
   type (Section 10.3.1).  HTTP/1.1 senders MUST NOT produce messages
   that include line folding (i.e., that contain any field-content that
   matches the obs-fold rule) unless the message is intended for
   packaging within the message/http media type.  HTTP/1.1 recipients
   SHOULD accept line folding and replace any embedded obs-fold
   whitespace with a single SP prior to interpreting the field value or
   forwarding the message downstream.

I.e., the parser still SHOULD be able to handle them, but the spec now admits they're not widely supported.

@pgriess - With HTTP/1.0 or earlier, Keep-Alive is disabled by default. Therefore, I think that we do not need it. Keep-Alive is used if and only if the response has `Connection: Keep-Alive` (or legacy `Keep-Alive:`, but http-parser does not seem to support it).

The case we're dealing with here is not that we can't determine the response length -- it's that we know that the length is 0.

issues.title: Conan package for http-parser
issues.body:
Hello,
Do you know about [Conan](https://github.com/conan-io/conan)?
[Conan](http://docs.conan.io/en/latest/) is modern dependency manager for C++. And will be great if your library will be available via package manager for other developers.

[Here](https://github.com/bincrafters/conan-templates) you can find example, how you can create package for the library. 

If you have any questions, just ask :-)

issues.title: Test "CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST" maybe worng
issues.body:
See: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235#issuecomment-356903686

The `CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST` test case input has `Content-Length: 10` and a body `"blarfcicle"`, but the test expects [`.body= ""`](https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/blob/master/test.c#L1102) !

[The RFC says](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3):
> _The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
    Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field.  Request message
   framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
   not define any use for a message body._

i.e. A request that says `Content-Length: 10` has a 10-byte body irrespective of the method being `CONNECT`.

The `CONNECT` scemantics are defined here: [RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6). It talks about the client ignoring *responses( with Content-Length in, however, that is not relevant to this test *request* test case.

>    _A server MUST NOT send any Transfer-Encoding or Content-Length header
   fields in a 2xx (Successful) response to CONNECT.  A client MUST
   ignore any Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header fields received
   in a successful response to CONNECT._

[RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6) goes on to say that a payload on a `CONNECT` request has no defined meaning, but it does not disallow it:

>  _A payload within a CONNECT request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a CONNECT request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request._

So, this line may be wrong: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235/files#diff-5c62f371bf37583234d2462ad49ce33dR1837

issues.title: HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields
issues.body:
According to https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/AsImplemented.html, HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields, and single CR + LF pair (or just LF) after a request line signals the end of request. But current http-parser waits for 2nd CR + LF pair. See how apache works: ``` $ telnet 127.0.0.1 80 Trying 127.0.0.1... Connected to 127.0.0.1. Escape character is '^]'. GET /

It works!

This is the default web page for this server.

The web server software is running but no content has been added, yet.

Connection closed by foreign host. ```

issues.title: When parsing response that omits status message text, on_status is never called
issues.body:
On status callback does not get invoked when we're dealing with a web server that omits the status text from the status line. Examples of servers doing this are kijiji.

Example from in the wild:
```
GET 
https://www.kijiji.ca/h-lloydminster-ab/1700095

Status: HTTP/1.1 200
```

Server is advertised as being nginx.

When parsing the response, `on_status` will never be called. Not sure if this is intended or not, I started looking into the spec for this and didn't see any `MUST`'s with regards to the status text. I came up with a solution to work around this personally so I don't care anymore, just FYI.

```

issues.title: How to disable automatic chunks decoding?
issues.body:
> The parser decodes the transfer-encoding for both requests and responses transparently. That is, a chunked encoding is decoded before being sent to the on_body callback.

Is it possible to configure parser not to decode chunked encoding?
I would like to receive chunks in `on_body` unmodified.

issues.title: http header parsing
issues.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

issues.body:
Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

issues.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
issues.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

issues.title: http-parser fails to detect chunked encoding at the end of a list
issues.body:
Given the header:

```
Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked\r\n
```

The parser will not set chunked encoding when it should:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.1

Encodings are applied left to right and removed from right to left. If the parser encounters the `chunked` token as the last item when the Transfer-Encoding value is a comma separated list, it should consider the message body to be chunk encoded.

I haven't actually tried this so I might be wrong but I see no code for finding a comma in Transfer-Encoding. However, the parser DOES handle comma separated lists correctly for the Connection header.

added ignore_header_transfer_encodig_chunked and ignore_header_content_length to settings.

  useful if body length and content length does not match. happens with owa servers. or working with pre http assemblers that unzips compressed content without changing content-length.

pull_requests.title: http header parsing
pull_requests.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

pull_requests.body: I've only tested this in freebsd-12.0 where the changes get me from syntax errors in the Makefile to passing `port test` with flying colors.

pull_requests.title: parser: fix handling of newlines before HTTP responses
pull_requests.body: This diff fixes ignoring of CR and LF chars received before HTTP response's start line the same way as they are handled with HTTP_REQUEST and HTTP_BOTH parser types.

pull_requests.title: makefile: Flexible install fixes
pull_requests.body:
Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

pull_requests.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
pull_requests.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

pull_requests.title: Allow non-standard HTTP method
pull_requests.body:
This change adds non-standard HTTP method support.  We added new
callback on_method of type http_data_cb, which notifies incoming
method.  For non-standard HTTP method, method field in struct
http_parser becomes HTTP_METHOD_UNKNOWN.

The non-standard HTTP method is disabled by default, and must be
explicitly enabled by giving -DHTTP_PARSER_METHOD_CB=1 on build time.
This is for backward compatibility; because non-standard HTTP method
is now accepted rather than rejected.

pull_requests.title: Fix: suppress warning C4244 on MSVC
pull_requests.body:
MSVC 2015 gives some warnings on http_parser.c with 

> warning C4244: '=' : conversion from 'int' to 'uint16_t', possible loss of data
> It will supress this warning.

pull_requests.title: http_parser: skip lws/rws in header field
pull_requests.body:
Skip whitespace from the left and the right sides of the header field.

See: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5844

cc @jasnell

pull_requests.title: Added support for compiling on MinGW platform
pull_requests.body:
Added rules to compile on MinGW platforms (Microsoft Windows environments):
- Use 'gcc' as compiler.
- Generate DLL file when compiling the library.
- Disable -fPIC when compiling the library (on MinGW platforms all code is already position independent and setting this flag issues an error).

pull_requests.title: Introduce raw data callbacks
pull_requests.body:
These callbacks can be used when developing transparent HTTP traffic analysis and filtering. 
The main goal of it is to handle transmitted data as-is, but having ability to distinguish data between headers, bodies and different requests.

pull_requests.title: Add support for digits, '+', '-', and '.' to the scheme of a URI
pull_requests.body: Addresses #275.

pull_requests.title: Make library symlinks relative
pull_requests.body: This allows distributions to be more easily relocatable, such as when bottling this library in Homebrew.

pull_requests.title: Implement on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks
pull_requests.body:
This patch adds on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks. 
When parser finish processing of new portion of data (or when it switches between header/body state) it run these callbacks, attaching exact stream data.
These callbacks called after usual header and body callbacks.

Patch contains bug: after parsing error detected it still can call raw callback, so we need to check error status of a parser inside raw callbacks.

Patch based at old revision, so we need to dig into parser logic again.
Base revision: 959f4cb12748ea3aa2c4ec3183ff4acbf0fd222f

pull_requests.title: Allow repeatable calls to 'make install'.
pull_requests.body:
Currently if `make install` is invoked multiple times it fails due to it trying to recreate the `libhttp_parser.so` symlink. 

Adding the `-f` flag to the `ln` invocations fixes this, but will change the default http-parser used to the newly installed version if there are multiple versions installed. I _think_ this is what we want to do anyway since we are clobbering any existing `http-parser.h` during install, so not repointing the symlink would result in a mismatch between the default library and header versions.

The alternative would be to version `http-parser.h` and add a symlink for it, while trying to ensure we always update both symlinks atomically.

pull_requests.title: Added support for SOURCE
pull_requests.body:
As per tweets: https://twitter.com/indutny/status/557499042243289088

It seems new handling for upgrade was added at some point, which makes the tests break. Unfortunately I don't have time to work out how to make the tests pass again.

SOURCE should essentially be handled like Upgrade, I believe, and switched to data/tcp mode after parsing headers.

/cc @indutny @bnoordhuis

pull_requests.title: Solaris doesn't necessarily have stdint.h, use inttypes.h
pull_requests.body:
Solaris doesn't necessarily have `stdint.h`, it's more portable to use `sys/inttypes.h`.

See:
http://wiki.opencsw.org/porting-faq#toc1

pull_requests.title: Add two hooks to be executed when a chunk is downloaded.
pull_requests.body:
One hook is executed right before receiving a new chunk. The second
one is executed just after. parsertrace.c is updated to use those
hooks for display.

I am using this for experimentation with rendering. This is more reliable than looking at timestamps to know where chunks start and end.

If I manually break parsing, I've got a reason to and I most probably want to communicate that reason back to the code that called `http_parser_execute` so that code can decide what steps to take next.

So please add this feature. :-)
You can communicate your state (or what action to take) to the code calling `http_parser_execute()` through your `void *data` object.
Can you please provide a dump of such a request?

A sample request from http://muffin.doit.org/docs/rfc/tunneling_ssl.html:

CONNECT home.netscape.com:443 HTTP/1.0
User-agent: Mozilla/1.1N
Proxy-authorization: basic aGVsbG86d29ybGQ=

I can get a dump, but from the sample it is pretty obvious what the problem is...

The parser fails when it encounters the first period in the hostname as it assumes it is parsing the schema, not the hostname!
I guess an easy fix would be to skip directly to _s_req_host state_ instead of _s_req_schema_ iff the request is a CONNECT...
closing.
Fixed in 4cf39fd2fa8d1b52338ad3c4dd9ae6b3f32d72f4.
Thanks for the report. Fixed in 120f0f6e09773dbe003841b5b339f9284dd63aad.
Fixed in d0dfc987732a25ee1f2236526e2801f06678cda4
ok

Just FYI, HTTPbis is discouraging the use of multi-line headers; from http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-11#section-3.2 : 

   Historically, HTTP header field values could be extended over
   multiple lines by preceding each extra line with at least one space
   or horizontal tab character (line folding).  This specification
   deprecates such line folding except within the message/http media
   type (Section 10.3.1).  HTTP/1.1 senders MUST NOT produce messages
   that include line folding (i.e., that contain any field-content that
   matches the obs-fold rule) unless the message is intended for
   packaging within the message/http media type.  HTTP/1.1 recipients
   SHOULD accept line folding and replace any embedded obs-fold
   whitespace with a single SP prior to interpreting the field value or
   forwarding the message downstream.

I.e., the parser still SHOULD be able to handle them, but the spec now admits they're not widely supported.

Hello,
Do you know about [Conan](https://github.com/conan-io/conan)?
[Conan](http://docs.conan.io/en/latest/) is modern dependency manager for C++. And will be great if your library will be available via package manager for other developers.

issues.title: Test "CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST" maybe worng
issues.body:
See: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235#issuecomment-356903686

The `CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST` test case input has `Content-Length: 10` and a body `"blarfcicle"`, but the test expects [`.body= ""`](https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/blob/master/test.c#L1102) !

[The RFC says](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3):
> _The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
    Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field.  Request message
   framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
   not define any use for a message body._

i.e. A request that says `Content-Length: 10` has a 10-byte body irrespective of the method being `CONNECT`.

The `CONNECT` scemantics are defined here: [RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6). It talks about the client ignoring *responses( with Content-Length in, however, that is not relevant to this test *request* test case.

>    _A server MUST NOT send any Transfer-Encoding or Content-Length header
   fields in a 2xx (Successful) response to CONNECT.  A client MUST
   ignore any Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header fields received
   in a successful response to CONNECT._

[RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6) goes on to say that a payload on a `CONNECT` request has no defined meaning, but it does not disallow it:

>  _A payload within a CONNECT request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a CONNECT request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request._

So, this line may be wrong: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235/files#diff-5c62f371bf37583234d2462ad49ce33dR1837

issues.title: HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields
issues.body:
According to https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/AsImplemented.html, HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields, and single CR + LF pair (or just LF) after a request line signals the end of request. But current http-parser waits for 2nd CR + LF pair. See how apache works: ``` $ telnet 127.0.0.1 80 Trying 127.0.0.1... Connected to 127.0.0.1. Escape character is '^]'. GET /

It works!

This is the default web page for this server.

The web server software is running but no content has been added, yet.

Connection closed by foreign host. ```

issues.title: When parsing response that omits status message text, on_status is never called
issues.body:
On status callback does not get invoked when we're dealing with a web server that omits the status text from the status line. Examples of servers doing this are kijiji.

Example from in the wild:
```
GET 
https://www.kijiji.ca/h-lloydminster-ab/1700095

Status: HTTP/1.1 200
```

Server is advertised as being nginx.

When parsing the response, `on_status` will never be called. Not sure if this is intended or not, I started looking into the spec for this and didn't see any `MUST`'s with regards to the status text. I came up with a solution to work around this personally so I don't care anymore, just FYI.

issues.title: http header parsing
issues.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

Fixing three Makefile related things,

1. LIBDIR should be configurable. INCLUDEDIR as well
2. fix SONAME so it represents actual ABI compatibility
3. symlinks should not have absolute paths

issues.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
issues.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

issues.title: http-parser fails to detect chunked encoding at the end of a list
issues.body:
Given the header:

```
Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked\r\n
```

The parser will not set chunked encoding when it should:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.1

Encodings are applied left to right and removed from right to left. If the parser encounters the `chunked` token as the last item when the Transfer-Encoding value is a comma separated list, it should consider the message body to be chunk encoded.

I haven't actually tried this so I might be wrong but I see no code for finding a comma in Transfer-Encoding. However, the parser DOES handle comma separated lists correctly for the Connection header.

pull_requests.title: ignore headers transfer_encoding_chunked and content_length to work with http assemblers.
pull_requests.body:
added ignore_header_transfer_encodig_chunked and ignore_header_content_length to settings.

ignore_header_content_length:
  useful if body length and content length does not match. happens with owa servers. or working with pre http assemblers that unzips compressed content without changing content-length.

ignore_header_transfer_encodig_chunked:
  useful when working with pre-http assemblers which assembles chunked content into one http packet without changing transfer-encoding field.

may be useful for someone.

pull_requests.title: http header parsing
pull_requests.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

pull_requests.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
pull_requests.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

pull_requests.title: Allow non-standard HTTP method
pull_requests.body:
This change adds non-standard HTTP method support.  We added new
callback on_method of type http_data_cb, which notifies incoming
method.  For non-standard HTTP method, method field in struct
http_parser becomes HTTP_METHOD_UNKNOWN.

The non-standard HTTP method is disabled by default, and must be
explicitly enabled by giving -DHTTP_PARSER_METHOD_CB=1 on build time.
This is for backward compatibility; because non-standard HTTP method
is now accepted rather than rejected.

pull_requests.body:

> warning C4244: '=' : conversion from 'int' to 'uint16_t', possible loss of data
> It will supress this warning.

Skip whitespace from the left and the right sides of the header field.

See: https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/5844

cc @jasnell

pull_requests.title: Added support for compiling on MinGW platform
pull_requests.body:
Added rules to compile on MinGW platforms (Microsoft Windows environments):
- Use 'gcc' as compiler.
- Generate DLL file when compiling the library.
- Disable -fPIC when compiling the library (on MinGW platforms all code is already position independent and setting this flag issues an error).

pull_requests.title: Introduce raw data callbacks
pull_requests.body:
These callbacks can be used when developing transparent HTTP traffic analysis and filtering. 
The main goal of it is to handle transmitted data as-is, but having ability to distinguish data between headers, bodies and different requests.

pull_requests.title: Add support for digits, '+', '-', and '.' to the scheme of a URI
pull_requests.body: Addresses #275.

pull_requests.title: Make library symlinks relative
pull_requests.body: This allows distributions to be more easily relocatable, such as when bottling this library in Homebrew.

pull_requests.title: Implement on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks
pull_requests.body:
This patch adds on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks. 
When parser finish processing of new portion of data (or when it switches between header/body state) it run these callbacks, attaching exact stream data.
These callbacks called after usual header and body callbacks.

Patch contains bug: after parsing error detected it still can call raw callback, so we need to check error status of a parser inside raw callbacks.

Patch based at old revision, so we need to dig into parser logic again.
Base revision: 959f4cb12748ea3aa2c4ec3183ff4acbf0fd222f

pull_requests.title: Allow repeatable calls to 'make install'.
pull_requests.body:
Currently if `make install` is invoked multiple times it fails due to it trying to recreate the `libhttp_parser.so` symlink. 

Adding the `-f` flag to the `ln` invocations fixes this, but will change the default http-parser used to the newly installed version if there are multiple versions installed. I _think_ this is what we want to do anyway since we are clobbering any existing `http-parser.h` during install, so not repointing the symlink would result in a mismatch between the default library and header versions.

The alternative would be to version `http-parser.h` and add a symlink for it, while trying to ensure we always update both symlinks atomically.

pull_requests.title: Added support for SOURCE
pull_requests.body:
As per tweets: https://twitter.com/indutny/status/557499042243289088

It seems new handling for upgrade was added at some point, which makes the tests break. Unfortunately I don't have time to work out how to make the tests pass again.

SOURCE should essentially be handled like Upgrade, I believe, and switched to data/tcp mode after parsing headers.

/cc @indutny @bnoordhuis

pull_requests.title: Solaris doesn't necessarily have stdint.h, use inttypes.h
pull_requests.body:
Solaris doesn't necessarily have `stdint.h`, it's more portable to use `sys/inttypes.h`.

See:
http://wiki.opencsw.org/porting-faq#toc1

pull_requests.title: Add two hooks to be executed when a chunk is downloaded.
pull_requests.body:
One hook is executed right before receiving a new chunk. The second
one is executed just after. parsertrace.c is updated to use those
hooks for display.

I am using this for experimentation with rendering. This is more reliable than looking at timestamps to know where chunks start and end.

Just FYI, HTTPbis is discouraging the use of multi-line headers; from http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-11#section-3.2 : 

   Historically, HTTP header field values could be extended over
   multiple lines by preceding each extra line with at least one space
   or horizontal tab character (line folding).  This specification
   deprecates such line folding except within the message/http media
   type (Section 10.3.1).  HTTP/1.1 senders MUST NOT produce messages
   that include line folding (i.e., that contain any field-content that
   matches the obs-fold rule) unless the message is intended for
   packaging within the message/http media type.  HTTP/1.1 recipients
   SHOULD accept line folding and replace any embedded obs-fold
   whitespace with a single SP prior to interpreting the field value or
   forwarding the message downstream.

I.e., the parser still SHOULD be able to handle them, but the spec now admits they're not widely supported.

I believe we need to be doing this status code check for HTTP/1.0 as well.

@pgriess - With HTTP/1.0 or earlier, Keep-Alive is disabled by default. Therefore, I think that we do not need it. Keep-Alive is used if and only if the response has `Connection: Keep-Alive` (or legacy `Keep-Alive:`, but http-parser does not seem to support it).

[EDIT] I may understand what you mean. HTTP/1.0 server sends `Connection: Keep-Alive`, but the body length may be unable to be determined.

Yeah, if the client and server both agree on keep-alive (i.e. by both sending "Connection: keep-alive" headers), we're dealing with the same situation as HTTP/1.1: we have a bytestream that contains a response with no body followed by another response. The case we're dealing with here is not that we can't determine the response length -- it's that we know that the length is 0.

issues.title: Conan package for http-parser
issues.body:
Hello,
Do you know about [Conan](https://github.com/conan-io/conan)?
[Conan](http://docs.conan.io/en/latest/) is modern dependency manager for C++. And will be great if your library will be available via package manager for other developers.

[Here](https://github.com/bincrafters/conan-templates) you can find example, how you can create package for the library. 

If you have any questions, just ask :-)

issues.title: Test "CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST" maybe worng
issues.body:
See: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235#issuecomment-356903686

The `CONNECT_WITH_BODY_REQUEST` test case input has `Content-Length: 10` and a body `"blarfcicle"`, but the test expects [`.body= ""`](https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/blob/master/test.c#L1102) !

[The RFC says](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3):
> _The presence of a message body in a request is signaled by a
    Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header field.  Request message
   framing is independent of method semantics, even if the method does
   not define any use for a message body._

i.e. A request that says `Content-Length: 10` has a 10-byte body irrespective of the method being `CONNECT`.

The `CONNECT` scemantics are defined here: [RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6). It talks about the client ignoring *responses( with Content-Length in, however, that is not relevant to this test *request* test case.

>    _A server MUST NOT send any Transfer-Encoding or Content-Length header
   fields in a 2xx (Successful) response to CONNECT.  A client MUST
   ignore any Content-Length or Transfer-Encoding header fields received
   in a successful response to CONNECT._

[RFC 7231, 4.3.6](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.6) goes on to say that a payload on a `CONNECT` request has no defined meaning, but it does not disallow it:

>  _A payload within a CONNECT request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a CONNECT request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request._

So, this line may be wrong: https://github.com/nodejs/http-parser/pull/235/files#diff-5c62f371bf37583234d2462ad49ce33dR1837

issues.title: HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields
issues.body:
According to https://www.w3.org/Protocols/HTTP/AsImplemented.html, HTTP/0.9 does not have header fields, and single CR + LF pair (or just LF) after a request line signals the end of request. But current http-parser waits for 2nd CR + LF pair. See how apache works: ``` $ telnet 127.0.0.1 80 Trying 127.0.0.1... Connected to 127.0.0.1. Escape character is '^]'. GET /

It works!

This is the default web page for this server.

The web server software is running but no content has been added, yet.

Connection closed by foreign host. ```

issues.title: When parsing response that omits status message text, on_status is never called
issues.body:
On status callback does not get invoked when we're dealing with a web server that omits the status text from the status line. Examples of servers doing this are kijiji.

Example from in the wild:
```
GET 
https://www.kijiji.ca/h-lloydminster-ab/1700095

Status: HTTP/1.1 200
```

Server is advertised as being nginx.

When parsing the response, `on_status` will never be called. Not sure if this is intended or not, I started looking into the spec for this and didn't see any `MUST`'s with regards to the status text. I came up with a solution to work around this personally so I don't care anymore, just FYI.

issues.title: http header parsing
issues.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

issues.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
issues.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

issues.title: http-parser fails to detect chunked encoding at the end of a list
issues.body:
Given the header:

```
Transfer-Encoding: gzip, chunked\r\n
```

The parser will not set chunked encoding when it should:
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.3.1

Encodings are applied left to right and removed from right to left. If the parser encounters the `chunked` token as the last item when the Transfer-Encoding value is a comma separated list, it should consider the message body to be chunk encoded.

I haven't actually tried this so I might be wrong but I see no code for finding a comma in Transfer-Encoding. However, the parser DOES handle comma separated lists correctly for the Connection header.

pull_requests.title: http header parsing
pull_requests.body:
http_parser along with other http request information supplies header
fields to the consumer. In `node` case, it creates a new `JSString`
of these header fields which involves memory allocation. If parser
keeps track of headers while parsing and return a unique id to `node`
that help distinguish the known header name, `node` don't have to
allocate for known headers and it can use the pre-created `JSString`
for the header fields. See discussion in https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/10930

The approach I have taken is while scanning the request, keep track
of known headers and update the `header_state` accordingly. `node` or
any consumer can consume the `header_state` information and decide
to use cached http header field instead of creating new string. I try to
match traditional cases http header. e.g. In Content-Type 'C' and 'T' has
to be upper case for the header to qualify for traditional cased header.
I use `traditional_case_http_headers` to track this information.

Performance is flat for node's http benchmark except bench-parse where
sometimes I noticed 5% regression. I am not sure if it was due to noise.

pull_requests.title: add settings flags, refactor lenient_http_headers setting
pull_requests.body:
A previous change during a security fix added the ability to set a `lenient_http_headers` flag on the HTTP Parser instance. The way it was done was a bit of a hack at the time in order to avoid an ABI breaking change. This PR adds a new `uint32_t` flags field to `http_parser_settings` in order to provide a more robust and correct way of passing these kinds of settings into a parser instance.

_Note_: This is an ABI change so it would require a semver-major bump

/cc @indutny

pull_requests.title: Allow non-standard HTTP method
pull_requests.body:
This change adds non-standard HTTP method support.  We added new
callback on_method of type http_data_cb, which notifies incoming
method.  For non-standard HTTP method, method field in struct
http_parser becomes HTTP_METHOD_UNKNOWN.

The non-standard HTTP method is disabled by default, and must be
explicitly enabled by giving -DHTTP_PARSER_METHOD_CB=1 on build time.
This is for backward compatibility; because non-standard HTTP method
is now accepted rather than rejected.

pull_requests.title: Introduce raw data callbacks
pull_requests.body:
These callbacks can be used when developing transparent HTTP traffic analysis and filtering. 
The main goal of it is to handle transmitted data as-is, but having ability to distinguish data between headers, bodies and different requests.

pull_requests.title: Implement on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks
pull_requests.body:
This patch adds on_header_raw and on_body_raw callbacks. 
When parser finish processing of new portion of data (or when it switches between header/body state) it run these callbacks, attaching exact stream data.
These callbacks called after usual header and body callbacks.

Patch contains bug: after parsing error detected it still can call raw callback, so we need to check error status of a parser inside raw callbacks.

Patch based at old revision, so we need to dig into parser logic again.
Base revision: 959f4cb12748ea3aa2c4ec3183ff4acbf0fd222f

pull_requests.title: Allow repeatable calls to 'make install'.
pull_requests.body:
Currently if `make install` is invoked multiple times it fails due to it trying to recreate the `libhttp_parser.so` symlink. 

Adding the `-f` flag to the `ln` invocations fixes this, but will change the default http-parser used to the newly installed version if there are multiple versions installed. I _think_ this is what we want to do anyway since we are clobbering any existing `http-parser.h` during install, so not repointing the symlink would result in a mismatch between the default library and header versions.

The alternative would be to version `http-parser.h` and add a symlink for it, while trying to ensure we always update both symlinks atomically.

pull_requests.body:

SOURCE should essentially be handled like Upgrade, I believe, and switched to data/tcp mode after parsing headers.

/cc @indutny @bnoordhuis

one is executed just after. parsertrace.c is updated to use those
hooks for display.

I am using this for experimentation with rendering. This is more reliable than looking at timestamps to know where chunks start and end.

Just FYI, HTTPbis is discouraging the use of multi-line headers; from http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-httpbis-p1-messaging-11#section-3.2 : 

   Historically, HTTP header field values could be extended over
   multiple lines by preceding each extra line with at least one space
   or horizontal tab character (line folding).  This specification
   deprecates such line folding except within the message/http media
   type (Section 10.3.1).  HTTP/1.1 senders MUST NOT produce messages
   that include line folding (i.e., that contain any field-content that
   matches the obs-fold rule) unless the message is intended for
   packaging within the message/http media type.  HTTP/1.1 recipients
   SHOULD accept line folding and replace any embedded obs-fold
   whitespace with a single SP prior to interpreting the field value or
   forwarding the message downstream.

I.e., the parser still SHOULD be able to handle them, but the spec now admits they're not widely supported.

@pgriess - With HTTP/1.0 or earlier, Keep-Alive is disabled by default. Therefore, I think that we do not need it. Keep-Alive is used if and only if the response has `Connection: Keep-Alive` (or legacy `Keep-Alive:`, but http-parser does not seem to support it).

[EDIT] I may understand what you mean. HTTP/1.0 server sends `Connection: Keep-Alive`, but the body length may be unable to be determined.

Yeah, if the client and server both agree on keep-alive (i.e. by both sending "Connection: keep-alive" headers), we're dealing with the same situation as HTTP/1.1: we have a bytestream that contains a response with no body followed by another response. The case we're dealing with here is not that we can't determine the response length -- it's that we know that the length is 0.

This doesn't catch URLs like `http://example.com:/`, v will be zero. I'm not sure if that's a bug or a feature.

Yeah, agreed that we should be validating that.

However, this isn't a regression. I'll file a bug for this. We have similar problems with handling empty hosts as well, both of which probably need a new state to indicate the beginning of the entity so that we can verify that there is at least one character.

You need to preserve `parser->data`.

review_comments.body:
No, to make it easier to detect overflow (signed overflow is undefined, unsigned overflow is not).

`(uint64_t) -1` is a shorthand / fallback for ULLONG_MAX.

Yes-ish. The reason that I don't is that `<limits.h>` doesn't always define it. I can add something like this:

``` c
#include <limits.h>

#ifndef ULLONG_MAX
#define ULLONG_MAX ((uint64_t) -1)
#endif
```

Your call.

Sorry, missed this one. Don't use `u_int`, it's a POSIX-ism.
What's this supposed to do?

Oh, I think I get it - you need to know _if_ this version of http-parser is compiled in debug mode.

I initially read it as a switch to turn on/off debug mode.

Correct. This could be a function, but I choose a constant variable since accessing them via FFI is cheaper than function calls.

In http-parser 2.0, `HTTP_PARSER_DEBUG` can dramatically change the layout of `http_parser`, so I need to check if debug was enabled when defining my own [FFI Struct](https://github.com/postmodern/ffi-http-parser/blob/master/lib/ffi/http/parser/instance.rb#L11-33).
Wrap at 80 columns.
